P.FONT: very intense, has a dark/futuristic quality
happy, corny sound, cheesy. Unusual mix of electronic and acoustic instruments increases the cornyness

identify common rhythmic or melodic components which could bind the transition aesthically - immediatly apparant is the snare drum on beats 2 and 4 in Source and the organ stab on beats 2 and 4 in target. Need to devise a strategy to overhall the instrumental mix, would layer in the changes one at a time to proceed through the transition; with something through it to hold it all together. Could use a varying filter to mask the changes also. Work out if there are any beats per minute changes which need to occur. If so, could use this as an impact change somehow and get through a few instrumental changes at the same time through impact. Changing the looping lines would take consideration - big aesthetic change, can the bass play target riff inside source? are they the same key, or does there need to be modulation? Huge overall aesthetic change, from dark brooding intense futuristic to corny cheese riffmaster, with sounds like chicken sounds at start??? have to map out the emotional change...minor? major?

modulation change though the circle of 5ths, especially if getting from minor to major. I'd probably go wit a breakdown on source, high pass filter on the bass, some modulation through the tonal centre and try to introduce some riff from target. Definitly up the drum work from source to get it up to target...maybe that could serve as the glue to bind the transition? Take 1/2 the target riff, in this case bass, of target and loop that in a buildup to the target...well thats some starting thoughts
SOURCE:mood of the music transition from intense brooding to cheesemaster target hard

nice breakdown and modal shift helps get the bass in the right direction, though it feels a little uncomfortable in the last section with the rhythmic devices prior to shifting into the target bass rift.

target seems like response, ie call and response source being call and target being response. quite nice overall...i enjoyed the harmonic shift and exposition of source through the morph, but the jump into different instruments into target coupled with bass being driven hard by kick made the bass change really noticable and detracted from the experience.

i found the bass change jarring through the latter of the morph, still being driven hard by kick but with the change in istrumentation making this change really noticible. there seemed little to mask this change - it was out there on its own with only the stabbing organ to help it along, when before there was the high descending note, maybe if this was reversed into an ascending, opening, sound as the sound opened up spacially, into major? and mask this transition further?
wow this is going somewhere.
change in range, metre feels slower more groovy
geez, calm that bass down! even though this bass is playing the riff for the second time, it stands out to much, with little else to add interest
dynamics and articulation
great, a bridging sound between these "4 on the floor" riffs
structure texture timbre
bongo/congo riff upbeat driving along, but gives hint of more and guides through modal change
rhythmic tecture pace metre

i think it would work, provided the visual/contextual content helped with the emotional aesthetic change from dark brooding to happier..im interested to see where it could go after target, cause this change is quite short and source is still "looming" on the background. This is probably due to the gradual exposition nature of the morph, rather than a specific stop then start next theme approach, in my opinion.

well, id go through and try to improve the problems i mentioned earler. take the good bits and use them more, remove or adjust the bad bits. good bits include some of the masking sounds i liked through the morph, bad bits like the bass just prior to the target, even though the volume atttenuation might be hard to adjust; that bass is so loud in the target
id explore some of the interesting ideas that emerged, particualry that harmonic counter melody when th bass dropped to the next key. That just screamed explore this idea to me!

the breakdown with some reference to later sounds, especially the chicken. it feels like its lost direction and doesn't know which way to go for a while, some key dissonance going on also, perhaps in the implied harmony
effect was not good, having to endure the ambiguity the final breakdown to the kick and chords at :15 was a real relief
i guess, if by favorable you mean finding comfort in relief from ambiguity. getting into the target was well done from the complete breakdown and worked well
where is the tonal centre? there did this ambiguity from from?
texture, timbre, structure,
back to tonal centre and relief from ambiguity
density, timbre, pitch tonality structure
great here we go again, it works well getting out of the breakdown into the target
rhythms, pitch, texture, timbre, dnesity
bass up an octive driving it in a different direction interesting, but this may be why i lost direction on tonal centre as so much is being driven by the bass
texture, timbre, range
No - to much "what the heck is that" going on - it is too ear catching and as thus stands out to much. Only when it reaches the complete breakdown prior to the target entry is there comfort.
strip out a lot of the complexity in the early breakdown and assist getting there with some volume attenuations. cut out the chicken sound completly until into the target
build it up more before the breakdown
cool, smoky room jazz electronica
wheres my atari 2600!
pitch of instruments, have a keys sound in source so use this to bridge into target
take excerpts from the target melody to play in source at the slower tempo, some bridgind sound and hit it with the fast target
timbre, tempo
hmm surprisingly this works quite well, that target music is so different. the key changes is REALLY interesting with the bass. intense change, uplifting, then dark then resolute into the new key
it helped to carry me into this new world of bizarre computer-ish music

sweet key , love that bass note
timbre, pitch
some interesting keys coming in
pitch, texture, timbre
big texture change with many synths on key change
texture, pace picks up
pace picks up, driven by opening cymbal
texture, pace, structure, density, metre
yes, i think it works. it has a steady range of instruments throughout (pitch range) even though they branch off into different rhythmic and melodic directions
maybe put a reference to the melody at 0:33 in a bit earlier
ditto, i think it works well

great quality, parts brought in earlier into the morph transition recognised, that little synth melody. Happy, feel good morph. Interesting drum break in the middle nice, pre-curser to the drums later on, but nice how it started then ended for a while.
a lot, because i found it interesting i found the transition nice
i enjoyed this morph, i think that having more time for the morph transition to occur over has helped in producing a smoother transition
nice little synth pre-curser comes in
rhythm, pitch, texture range change interesting to listen to
sounded good with counter melody synth in mid range
metre, playing a different metre/rhythm against, and it had already been introduced fleetingly at 0:8 an octive higher. Timbre, pitch articulation interesting
nice sounds
drums getting busy, rhythmic interesting and texture timbre change. opening cymbal creates a sense of space. dynamics and pace increasing
change of instrumentation focus nice that drums built up to this
timbre, dynamics pitch change, structure has clearly changed direction and rhythm
most definitly, this is a good morph to get between two very different musical ideas. it transitions smoothly and in an interesting way.

slight adjustment of the 6/8 melody at around 0:26; it feels a little lost harmonically briefly at that point. Maybe remove a few notes there to create some space and get through that difficult transition.
ditto
not very intense, not to happy, just sort of normal sounding as a mood.
action, fast paced intense music.
use the drums to get through as they are similiar in structure. maybe try getting the guitar to move down an octive and move into becoming the electronic bass part on the target
move the cymbal on beat 1 from target in early into the morph with the drums building up. strings from source to vary into target , maybe a bit of both
tempo change provides a challenge, model change. Density and articulation attack more assertive in target, yet relaxed in source
did not like this, it sounded like two different tracks were playing at the same time
i did not enjoy the morphs smoothness from the start, so this detracted on my subjective response
in the later part of the morph it was smooth, the start and first half was unconfident in sound

this sounds ok

I dont think this would be successful, due to the odd start to the morph. It sounds like two different tracks are playing at the same time.
try and tidy up the start of the morph a bit, perhaps try and remove some clutter in the bottom end

works ok, theres a few odd moments but generally it gets there. quality goes from happy to more intense as the drums kick along driving it. recognise parts shift from guitar to synth up an octivce felt a good choice
a lot, at first it sounded lost, but in the middle it found its feet and i could follow the transition better
change nice with the chord modulation prior to the drums kicking in

to bottom heavy, the notes are two close together for the low pitch.

some good quality, happy sounds, recognise parts as they move through this transition

few years in a rock band, listen almost exclusively to metal and rock. Then got into experimental instrumental music, then discovered the joy of midi. Completed a degree in jazz guitar, listened almost excluisevly to jazz for three years, and percussionist in local orchestra listend to classical. Grad dip then Master music interactive music technologies, electronica etc. Enjoy all styles.
